dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The famous red awning with COPACABANA in white block lett hangs over the entrance of the world-renowned nightclub. long line of well-dressed customers fills the sidewalk waiting to get in. OVER THIS - WE HEAR the opening horns of Bobby Rydell’s version of “THAT OLD BLACK MAGIC”...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vibe is electric. SIX HUNDRED PATRONS pack the tables the main room. Brazilian in theme, the Copa décor is art throughout, filled with palm trees illuminated by blue an pink hues. Pure elegance. Peppering the crowd... gorgeous COPA GIRLS, white-jackete WAITERS, MAITRE D’S in Black Tuxedo Jackets, CAPTAINS in Tux Jackets, and BOUNCERS in Red Tux Jackets. On stage in front of the Orchestra, tuxedo-clad BOBBY RYD The crowd APPLAUDS.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RYDELL
dialogues.text: Thank you very much! Welcome to Jules Podell’s Copacabana! I’m Bobby Rydell and I’m happy to be here! (singing) That old Black Magic has me in its spell... THE SONG CONTINUES THROUGH THIS ENTIRE SEQUENCE... FRANK “TONY LIP” VALLELONGA, 40s, Copa bouncer, moves qui through the crowd. Lip is imposing with a charismatic presence. You don’t mess with this guy. Following Lip, an ATTRACTIVE COUPLE. Lip leads them to a table near the front of the stage. The man slips Lip some cash. The Orchestra kicks in big, the room is jumping... At a back booth, JULES PODELL, 60, Copa owner, a tough-as nails bulldog of a man. He taps his diamond ring on the t to the beat of the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip trolls for customers who will tip him for a table. He NOTICES... JOEY LOSCUDO, 50s, a Mob Boss, entering the club followed his CREW. Loscudo walks over to the COAT-CHECK GIRL, take off his coat and hat, hands them to her.

dialogues.speaker: LOSCUDO
dialogues.text: Guard this hat with your life... My mother gave it to me. He winks.

dialogues.speaker: COAT-CHECK GIRL
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Loscudo... He hands the Coat-Check Girl some money. The MAITRE D’, CARMINE, walks over.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Joey!

dialogues.speaker: LOSCUDO
dialogues.text: Hey, Carmine! Carmine slips Lip some cash.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: That’s not necessary...

dialogues.speaker: LOSCUDO
dialogues.text: Come on. You know I saw this kid Rydell last year in Philly. Nobody knew who he was.

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Well they know him now... They hug, then Carmine escorts Loscudo and his ENTOURAGE the main room. Lip approaches the Coat-Check Girl.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Gimme Loscudo’s hat.

dialogues.speaker: COAT-CHECK GIRL
dialogues.text: But he said...

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I know, just give it to me... He bangs her a couple bucks, she turns the hat over to hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RYDELL’S STILL SINGING, THE JOINT’S ROCKING... A FIGHT br out... FOUR GOOMBAHS pound each other. Tables flip, glass breaks, patrons scream... ANGLE ON Podell as he jumps up...

dialogues.speaker: TONY LIIIIIIIIIIIIIP
dialogues.text: Lip is already on the move, running to the fight... It’s pandemonium, but Rydell doesn’t stop. He and the Orchestra building the speed and intensity of the song... Lip is joined by Carmine, and some BOUNCERS, all of them grappling with the Goombahs. They quickly RUSH THEM OUT O THE ROOM....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone comes CRASHING out the front door. Lip throws th Goombah down the steps to the street. He jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Do yourself a favor--go home with your friends.

dialogues.speaker: GOOMBAH
dialogues.text: Don’t you tell me where to go! Do you know who I am?! I’m goin’ back in there!

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Nah, you’re not. The Goombah TAKES A SWING at Lip and it’s on. Lips KNOCKS ON HIS ASS, then jumps on him and starts to BASH HIS FACE CLOSE ON - Lip, brutally punching, his fists bloody, as W HEAR O.S. APPLAUSE and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band’s swinging as Bobby Rydell delivers the big clim to the song... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY RYDELL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (singing) .--Whoa, that old Black Magic called looocooccocve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of people wait behind mob boss Joey Loscudo as he screams at the Coat-Check Girl. Carmine stands by.

dialogues.speaker: LOSCUDO
dialogues.text: I‘1l burn this place down! Where's my hat!

dialogues.speaker: COAT-CHECK GIRL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mr. Loscudo, I went to the ladies room, I was only gone a minute...

dialogues.speaker: LOSCUDO
dialogues.text: Someone better find it!

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: It‘ll turn up, I swear it’ll turn up.

dialogues.speaker: LOSCUDO
dialogues.text: Really? You tell that fat Jew bastard Podell that if it doesn’t turn up, I'll burn this place down! You hear me? I’ll burn the Copa down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip, Carmine, and another bouncer, DANNY, smoke cigarette lean against a dinged-up ‘55 BUICK Sedan. A poster at the Copa entrance reads: BOBBY RYDELL - SOLD A worker pastes a banner over it: COPA CLOSED FOR RENOVAT NOVEMBER/DECEMBER -— SEE YOU IN JANUARY WITH SAMMY DAVIS,

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. Loscudo is out of his mind.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We earned our money tonight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: Lip, I thought you were gonna kill that guy.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Better him than me. What are you gonna do while we're closed?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe work at my Uncle’s pizza joint.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (to Carmine) What about you?

dialogues.speaker: CARMINE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna drink for two months. The men straighten up as Jules Podell exits the club.

dialogues.speaker: JULES PODELL
dialogues.text: Take me home, Lip.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. JILLY’S SALOON - NIGHT LOSCUDO’S HAT GETS PLOPPED IN THE MIDDLE OF A TABLE... PULL BACK... Luscudo sits in the corner booth, holding co with JILLY and friends.

dialogues.speaker: LOSCUDO
dialogues.text: My hat! Jesus Christ, if you had tits, I’d kiss ya! How the hell’d you find it? ANGLE ON LIP standing in front of the table.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Heard it was missing, so I looked into it.

dialogues.speaker: LOSCUDO
dialogues.text: I wanted to kill that broad.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Wasn't her fault.

dialogues.speaker: JILLY RIZZO
dialogues.text: Who had the balls to clip it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it, I took care of him.

dialogues.speaker: LOSCUDO
dialogues.text: I hope you gave him some beating. Loscudo pulls out a wad of cash, peels off a C-note.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No, I can’t. It was my pleasure, Mr. Loscudo. Loscudo SLAMS the MONEY into Lip’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: LOSCUDO
dialogues.text: Bullshit. And from now on you don’t have to call me Mister Loscudo, ya hear me? Lip smiles. EXT. LIP’S APARTMENT - BRONX - DAWN A six-story brick building with fire escapes framing the windows. Parked cars fill both sides of the street. Lip’s pulls up and parks in front of a FIRE HYDRANT. He gets ou grabs a garbage can, and PUTS IT OVER THE HYDRANT. INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - MORNING Lip ENTERS the small one-bedroom apartment. He moves to t kitchen, opens the refrigerator, chugs half a bottle of m INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - MORNING Lip ENTERS. Sleeping in the bed, Lip’s wife DOLORES, late 30s, pretty. Beside her, NICK, 9, and FRANKIE, 7. Lip takes off a ring, his watch, places them on top of th bureau. Empties his pockets of crumpled wads of cash. Lip strips down to a t-shirt and boxer shorts, gets in be snuggles up to Dolores. She wakes, kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: ‘Morning...

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: ‘Night...  INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: PHIL RIZUTTO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Roger Maris at the plate, Pierce checks the signs...” PULL BACK -- On the couch watching the game, Lip’s Father NICOLA, 70s, brother RUDY, 30s, Dolores’ father, ANTHONY, 70s, and her two brothers JOHNNY, 40s, and LOUIE, 30s.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Come on, Roger! Hit one out!

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Be quiet, you’re gonna jinx it! Lip ENTERS still wearing his t-shirt and white boxers.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Johnny, think you can yell a little louder?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Maris is up...

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah, so am I now. What the hell are you guys doing here? Johnny discreetly nods toward the kitchen where we see TW BLACK WORKMEN laying down linoleum. The kids, Nick and Fr play with plastic Green Army soldiers in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Figured we'd come up and keep Dolores company... BACK TO SCENE - Lip gets the point.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: (in Italian) You shouldn’t be sleeping in the middle of the day, leaving my daughter here alone with these sacks of coal.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLA
dialogues.text: (in Italian) And why do you hire them to do an Italian’s job? It’s a disgrace. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (in Italian) I don’t know who they’re gonna send. ON Dolores - she pours a couple glasses of lemonade and h the drinks to the Black Workmen.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK WORKMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma’am. Lip watches as the Workmen drink the lemonade, then Dolor takes the glasses and PUTS THEM IN THE SINK. As she leads men to the door, we go...

dialogues.speaker: PHIL RIZUTTO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Deep to center field, holy cow he did it! A home run for Roger Maris! Holy cow!” Johnny jumps up, they all CHEER... Except Lip, whose eyes keep darting toward the GLASSES IN SINK. Dolores comes back and Lip joins her in the kitchen pours himself a glass of water, dips his finger in the sa she’s cooking. Dolores slaps his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Get dressed, Tony, we’re gonna eat. She picks up a big platter of meatballs and sausage and t it into the dining room. Lip glances into the sink. CLOSE ON - The Black Workmen’s two empty lemonade glasses Lip takes the GLASSES out of the sink, DROPS THEM INTO TH GARBAGE.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - DINETTE - LATER Lip’s at the table, dressed now. Wine and plates of rigat Joining them for lunch are FRAN, Johnny's wife, and LYNN, Louie’s wife. Dolores makes the sign of the cross.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Bless us our Lord, for these thy gifts, which we are about to receive, from thy bounty through Christ our Lord, Amen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all make the sign of the cross.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLA
dialogues.text: Salute. They start stuffing their faces.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: If anyone hears about a job for Tony, let us know.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (nobody's business) Dolores...

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: What happened, you get fired?

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: No, Copa’s closing for repairs. He needs something for just a couple months.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I’1l ask around.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLA
dialogues.text: (in Italian) Mister big shot. Always spend, spend, spend. No job, he gets himself a new kitchen floor.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (in Italian) Come on, Pop. The kids were gettin’ splinters in their feet.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: All the people he knows, he'll find something.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He had a great job at the sanitation department. (to Lip) You shouldn’t have punched out the foreman.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: He shouldn’t have woke me up. Everyone LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - KITCHEN - DAY - LATER Dolores is cleaning up. She’s scraping a plate into the garbage can when she notices something 0O.S. DOLORES’ POV - Two empty glasses in the garbage... She SIGHS, disappointed in her husband, then picks up the glasses from the garbage pail and puts them back into the sink.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. GORMAN’S HOT DOGS - DAY Johnny, Lip, and Lip’s youngest boy, Frankie, ENTER.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I’m tellin’ you, this is gonna be the easiest fifty bucks you ever made. They walk over to a table where FAT PAULIE, 40s, is waiti with the owner, GORMAN, and a couple other CUSTOMERS.

dialogues.speaker: FAT PAULIE
dialogues.text: Johnny told me you ate forty-eight White Castle burgers in one sitting.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Cheeseburgers.

dialogues.speaker: FAT PAULIE
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What do I care if you believe me? (beat) Gorman, who’s got the record for hotdogs here?

dialogues.speaker: GORMAN
dialogues.text: Fat Paulie. Fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Why wasn’t Lip in on that contest?

dialogues.speaker: FAT PAULIE
dialogues.text: What contest? I was hungry. The guys CHUCKLE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GORMAN
dialogues.text: Bet’s simple. Half a C-note. Most hotdogs in an hour wins. With toppings. Lip sizes him up.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What the hell you weigh?

dialogues.speaker: FAT PAULIE
dialogues.text: Two-sixty.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Aaaaay. Your left ass weighs two- sixty. Fat Paulie raises his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: FAT PAULIE
dialogues.text: May my mother-in-law drop dead on the spot if I’m lyin’. They all LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Okay, you’re on.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT
dialogues.text: INT. GORMAN’S HOT DOGS - LATER The table filled with an assortment of hot dogs. Everyone CHEERS, CLAPS, as Lip and Fat Paulie STUFF THEIR FACES.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Come on, Lip, pick it up! The baby elephant just hit nineteen! Lip sweats, slows down, looks like he’s gonna puke. The c cheers as Fat Paulie calmly takes a big bite of another d

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - DAY Lip and Frankie ENTER. Frankie runs over to Nick who is d homework.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Nicky, you doin’ your homework? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Where were you? Lip plops down in a chair, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Gorman’s. Fat Paulie bet me fifty bucks he could eat more hot dogs than me. He knocked off twenty- eight. Guy’s an animal.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Are you crazy--you lost fifty dollars?!

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Dolores, please. I ate thirty. 12. Lip pulls out the winnings. She plucks the bills from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Thank God. The gas bill came in today. THE PHONE RINGS. Lip answers.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jules Podell sits at his table in the empty Copa. He sips a cup of coffee as WORKERS clear tablecloths, flip chairs o tables, etc.

dialogues.speaker: JULES PODELL
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey, Lip, some guy called over here -- a doctor’s lookin’ for a driver. You interested?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JULES PODELL
dialogues.text: They're interviewing guys tomorrow afternoon. Here’s the address.  13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip, wearing black slacks and a bowling-style shirt, stan at the front of... CARNEGIE HALL... He takes out a piece of paper, looks at it. This can’t be place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magnificent. Lip enters, moves down the aisle. He takes i the spectacle. WOMAN’S VOICE (0O.S.) Excuse me. We’re not open right now... Lip turns to face the BOX OFFICE MANAGER across the room.

dialogues.speaker: BOX OFFICE MANAGER
dialogues.text: But you’re welcome to buy tickets to tonight's performance.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: ‘There a doctor's office ‘round here? I think I got the wrong address. Lip holds up the paper.

dialogues.speaker: BOX OFFICE MANAGER
dialogues.text: You have the correct address. Dr. Shirley lives upstairs, above the hall. INT. DON SHIRLEY’S APARTMENT HALLWAY - DAY Lip walks down the hall. Two ENGLISH BUTLER-TYPES sit in chairs outside a door. The door opens and an ASIAN MAN, b suit and tie, carrying a briefcase, exits. At the door stands an Indian valet, AMIT, white Nehru shi white linen pants, clipboard in hand.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I'm here for the driver job. Tony Lip. Amit checks the list, flips a page, can’t find it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I should be on there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AMIT
dialogues.text: No Tony Lip. I do have a Tony Val...Valle...

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Vallelonga. That’s me.

dialogues.speaker: AMIT
dialogues.text: Fill this out while you wait.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AMIT
dialogues.text: Fill. It. Out. While you wait. Amit hands him a clipboard and a pen, then Lip takes a se next to the butlers. INT. SHIRLEY’S APARTMENT - DAY - LATER Amit escorts Lip in. CLASSICAL MUSIC PLAYS.

dialogues.speaker: AMIT
dialogues.text: Take a seat. Lip sits in a leather chair and Amit EXITS. Lip looks aro Never seen anything like it. Thirty-foot ceilings, giant skylight, enormous French windows overlooking Manhattan. It's filled to the rafters with paintings, African art, sculptures, Chinese lanterns, a giant gold Buddha, and tw six-foot elephant tusks. A crystal chandelier hangs above black Steinway Concert Grand Piano. A THRONE... an actual King’s throne... sits on a riser, b against the glass window.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Vallelonga, sorry to keep you waiting... Lip turns...Standing before him is DR. DONALD SHIRLEY, la 30s, black, resplendent in a traditional African robe. He bedecked in assorted chain necklaces, bracelets, watch, a rings. Dr. Shirley speaks in a clipped, refined manner.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I’m Dr. Donald Shirley. Lip’s taken aback. Not what he expected. He stands. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Hi. Tony. Shirley extends his hand. They shake.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Please, have a seat. Lip sits. Shirley sits on his “throne,” looking down at L

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: This is some place you got here. Motioning to the Elephant Tusks.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Them horns real?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Elephant tusks. Yes. Lip nods, points to the chain around Shirley’s neck.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What about that? That a molar?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: A molar. Lip points to his side teeth.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like a shark tooth? Or a tiger's?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Um, no. It was a gift.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Oh. (looks around) I thought I was going to an office. They said a doctor needed a driver.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: That’s all they told you? Lip shrugs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually, it’s a bit more complicated than that. Have you ever driven professionally before?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Sanitation. (beat) Garbage trucks. Off Shirley’s unimpressed look.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Plus I drive my boss home at night. I can drive anything.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I see. What other experience do you have?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I worked a lot of joints. The Wagon Wheel, Peppermint Lounge, Copa...

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: In what capacity?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: What did you do there? Lip chews on that. You can smell the wood burning...

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Public relations... Shirley nods, understanding.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Well, first of all, Tony, I’m nota medical doctor. I’m a musician.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: You mean like songs?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m about to start a concert tour, the majority of which will be down South.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Atlantic City? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: The deep south. We start in the midwest, but then we’re taking a hard left. Kentucky, North Carolina, Tennessee, and on down through the Delta. (beat) Do you foresee any issues working for a black man?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No, no... ‘fact just yesterday me and the wife had a couple colored guys over the house. For drinks. Shirley takes a BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. You’re married.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yup. Two kids.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I don’t know if this is the proper job for a married man.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Why, we bringing broads? Shirley shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: My point is, you’ll be gone for eight straight weeks--with no breaks--right up until Christmas. You're quite sure you can leave your family for that long?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Depends on what you’re paying.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Ninety dollars a week, plus room and board. But let me be crystal clear... I’m not simply hiring a chauffeur. I need someone who can handle my itinerary. I need a personal assistant. I need a valet. I need someone who will launder my clothes, shine my shoes...

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Good luck, Doc. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lip stands, heads for the door. Shirley steps down off hi throne.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Tony... Lip turns back, faces Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had my record label ask around town to find me the right man. Your name came up more than once. You’ve impressed a lot of people by the way you handle... trouble. That’s why I called and asked about your availability. Lip thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Look, I got no problem being on the road with you. But I ain’t no butler, I ain’t ironing shirts, and I’m not shining nobody's shoes. You need someone to get you from point A to point B? You need someone to make sure there’s no problems along the way -- and you going through the deep South, believe me, there's gonna be problems. So if you want me, it’s gotta be a buck and a quarter a week. Or go hire the little Chink that just pranced out of here and see how far you get. Shirley stares, stone-faced.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Vallelonga...thank you for coming in. As Lip turns and walks out, we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tired Lip comes walking down the sidewalk and ENTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoky, packed, loud... Lip snakes his way to BOBBY, 40s, CHINESE, who’s behind the bar. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Bobby, give me a Rheingold. Ice cold. Bobby pours a draft of Rheingold, slides it in front of h

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (concerned) Mister Tony. Augie asking about you. Lip isn’t happy to hear this. A CUSTOMER pounds on the ba

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Come on, I’m dying of thirst over here!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Shut up, I’m talking! He turns back to Lip.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Now. He in his box. Lip drains the beer, leaves the bar area, weaves his way through the crowd to an ENCLOSED, PRIVATE BOOTH with a curtain blocking the people inside. Lip hesitates, then o the curtain. HIS POV - AUGIE, rough-looking, dead eyes, sits there stuffing his face with linguini and clam sauce. TWO PSYCHOPATHS sit with him. The Psychos look on blankly. A lesser man would shit his pants.

dialogues.speaker: AUGIE
dialogues.text: (intense) Tony Lip. What the hell happened at the Copa? I heard you split a guy’s face open. Lip shrugs. AUGIE (CONT’D) That guy you hit. He was one of Charlie the Hand’s crew.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Then he shoulda known better. (CONTINUED)
Augie mad-dogs him, never losing eye contact as he stuffs face. Lip doesn’t blink.

dialogues.speaker: AUGIE
dialogues.text: The Hand wanted me to look into it. I spoke to Podell. Whole thing was over a piece of ass, right? Lip shrugs. AUGIE (CONT’D) A beef like that should never happen in the club. They were out of line. So we squashed it. He wipes olive oil off his chin. AUGIE (CONT’D) Sit down. Have something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Thanks, but I already ate. Augie chews away, not sure if he believes him.

dialogues.speaker: AUGIE
dialogues.text: You looking to earn some extra scharole? I could keep you busy while the Copa’s down.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What I gotta do?

dialogues.speaker: AUGIE
dialogues.text: Things... Lip thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Appreciate it, but I’m gonna spend some time with the family.

dialogues.speaker: AUGIE
dialogues.text: Don’t be stupid. You can make a few bucks, buy something nice for your wife.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I’m good. I’m flush right now. cur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The EL TRAIN thunders above Lip as he enters a PAWN SHOP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Lip’s WRISTWATCH on the counter. The pawn guy, CHARLIE, looks up at Lip, concerned. Reluctantly, he hand Lip cash and a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: PAWN GUY
dialogues.text: Here's fifty. Give me sixty before Christmas, you get it back. Lip turns to leave. PAWN GUY (CONT’D) Hey, Lip... everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (offended) You got beak trouble, Charlie? Mind your business. Lip walks out. INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Lip sits watching TV as Dolores hands him a bowl of spagh

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: So what happened with the doctor interview?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: He ain’t a real doctor, he’s a piano player. Lip digs in, starts stuffing his face.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: I don’t understand--why’d they say he was a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I think he’s like a doctor of piano-playing or something.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: You can be that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I guess. He lives on top of Carnegie Hall. You shoulda seen this place, Dee--it was filled with statues and all kinds of fancy crap. And he was sitting on a friggin’ throne all dressed up like the king of the jungle bunnies.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: He’s colored? You wouldn’t last a week with him.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: For the right money, I would. As Lip continues eating, we go... INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - EARLY MORNING Lip and Dolores are asleep in bed, the kids asleep in ano bed across the room. THE PHONE RINGS. Lip and Dolores wak up. Lip looks at the clock--8 a.m. He answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello... Yeah... Really?... Why?... Okay, hold on. Lip puts his hand over the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: It’s him.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Dr. Shirley, the piano guy. He wants to talk to you. She sits up.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: (whispers) Me? What? Why? Lip shrugs. He holds out the phone, Dolores takes it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello... Good morning, Doctor, nice to talk to you, too... She glances at Lip.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes, that is a long time... Dolores looks at Lip as Shirley talks on.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) It is...Yes, I’m sure...Thank you for calling...Goodbye. Dolores hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What he say? Dolores looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: He wanted to know if I'd be okay with him taking my husband away from his family for two months. He said he'd pay you what you asked for. Lip looks surprised. She rolls away from him.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: It’s good money, Dolores. You know we need it. I can’t be eatin’ thirty hot dogs every day. Dolores wells up.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: I know...I said it was okay for you to go. EXT. LIP’S APARTMENT - MORNING Dion's “RUNAROUND SUE” drifts lazily from a transistor radio... Laundry hangs from fire escapes. OLD ITALIAN WOM sit in folding chairs CHATTING while Grandpa Nicola, Gran Anthony and Rudy watch Nick and Frankie play. A 1963 CHRYSLER NEW YORKER and a 1961 CADILLAC SEDAN are parked in front. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lip, wearing a well-worn black suit, stands next to the Chrysler talking to a RECORD EXEC, 40s, sharply dressed, nonsense, and his nebbishy ASSISTANT. The Record Exec han Lip a check.

dialogues.speaker: RECORD EXEC
dialogues.text: Here's the first half of your pay. You’1ll get the rest when the tour’s over.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Uh-uh, I gotta get paid every week.

dialogues.speaker: RECORD EXEC
dialogues.text: Sorry, that’s not how the record company does it. Lip glares at him. RECORD EXEC (CONT’D) We gotta have some guarantee you’1ll finish the job.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Why the hell wouldn’t I finish the job? I took it, didn’t I? The Record Exec glances at his assistant, then back at Li

dialogues.speaker: RECORD EXEC
dialogues.text: Then you’ve got nothing to worry about. The Exec holds out the car keys. As Lip reaches for them, Exec pulls them back. RECORD EXEC (CONT’D) Here’s the deal, Mr. Vallelonga. It’s your job to get Don to all his tour dates on time. If he misses any shows, you’re not getting your back-end. Lip takes the keys.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: He’s not gonna miss any shows.

dialogues.speaker: RECORD EXEC
dialogues.text: Good. And you’re going to need this. He hands Lip a small GREEN BOOK. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: RECORD EXEC (CONT’D) It’s the book I told you about. Sometimes you're staying in the same hotels, and sometimes you’re not. As Lip glances at the book, we -- ANGLE ON Lip’s brother-in-law, Johnny, exiting the buildi He carries a suitcase over to the Cadillac. As the Record Exec and his assistant drive off in the Chrysler, Lip walks over to Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (re: Caddy) Madonne. This the new one?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: The record company rented it. Lip opens the trunk, Johnny puts the suitcase in.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: So what'd my sister say about you being gone for three weeks?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Eight weeks. Johnny smirks.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. Ten-to-one you slap the moolie out and come home under a month. Lip smiles, shoves Johnny. Dolores approaches with the ki

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Come here. Say goodbye to your father. Nick and Frankie run to Lip, hug him. They get emotional.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Stop that. You gotta be big boys, take care of your mother... HE give the kids kisses, then they run away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Did you go to the A-A-A for the maps?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: The record guy gave me maps and directions with the itinerary thing. And this. Lip pulls out the small green book that the Record Exec g him.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: (reading) The Negro Motorist Green-Book?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Lists all the places coloreds can stay down south. Like if you’re traveling while black.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Traveling while black?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah. Like if you’re black but you gotta travel for some reason.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: They got a special book for that?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Did you pack an iron?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I ain’t lugging around no iron, Dee.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: How you gonna keep your pants pressed?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I’1ll put ‘em under my mattress. Dolores takes Lip’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: I want you to write me a letter every chance you get. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Aw, come on, Dee, I can’t write letters.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Take you five minutes. Promise me.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I can’t write, it’s embarrassing-- they ain’t gonna be no good.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: It’s a lot cheaper than callin’ long distance, Tony. Promise me you'll write. Lip SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Okay. I promise. I’1l try. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah. Lip hugs and kisses her. He gives her the check.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put this in the bank today. She takes it and hands him a brown paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: I made a couple veal-cutlet sandwiches for you and Dr. Shirley. Be careful. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: You better be home at Christmas or don’t come home at all! As they kiss, Grandpa Nicola CALLS OUT to Lip:

dialogues.speaker: NICOLA
dialogues.text: (in Italian) He who arrives late has no bed! Lip waves goodbye to everyone. WE STAY ON Dolores as he drives away...  28.

dialogues.text: I’m Tony. You the band?

dialogues.text: Dr. Shirley’s Cadillac drives west on Route 80, followed Oleg and George.

dialogues.text: Lip’s driving fast, smoking faster. Shirley chokes on the blue haze filling the car, cracks his window. Lip reaches into the brown paper bag, pulls out a wax-pap wrapped sandwich with “Tony” written on it, peels back th foil. Veal cutlet and peppers sandwich on a loaf of Itali bread. Still smoking, Lip starts to eat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Tony, when we arrive in a city, the first thing I’d like you to do is check the piano where I’m playing. Make sure it’s a Steinway as per my contract. Lip pulls out a pen, writes “STAIN WAY” on the map.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And could you see to it that I have a bottle of Cutty Sark in my room every night.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Every night? Lip smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well if you ever need any help with that...

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I won't. And ten-and-two on the wheel, please. Tony loses the smile. Shirley slides over in his seat so he’s directly behind Lip. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Doc, I noticed on the itinerary thing there that the last show’s December 23rd.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Birmingham, yes. It’s a Christmas show.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Any way we could hit the road early the next morning so we could be back home in time for Christmas Eve?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: We'll see. Could you please put the cigarette out?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Because I can’t breathe back here.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Smoke’s going into my lungs. I’m doing all the work here.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Lip thinks about it, defiantly takes one long last drag o the heater, then another, then finally FLICKS IT OUTSIDE. Lip rolls up his window, shoots a look at the second sandwich, “Dr. Shirley” written on it. FUCK THIS GUY. He opens it, stuffs Shirley’s sandwich in his mouth, looks straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oleg’s car speeds up, pulls next to Shirley’s Cadillac. O rolls down his window, motions to Shirley, who rolls down window. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: (in Russian) Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (in Russian) Yes. Everything's fine. Lip looks back over his shoulder, stunned to hear Shirley speaking in another language.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: (in Russian) Good. We’ll meet you at the hotel in Pittsburgh.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (in Russian) Make a reservation for dinner. We'll rehearse immediately after. See you there. Oleg gives Lip the hairy eyeball, blows past him.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (to himself) Hell’s he looking at? Lip looks in the mirror at Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You speak German, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: That was Russian.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was stationed in Germany in the army. I can pick up a little of what you’re sayin’. Be careful, Krauts are all sneaks. Kennedy shoulda bombed ‘em when we had the chance--plus now them Cuban bastards. Shirley rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where they going anyway? Ain’t they supposed to be following us? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: They have the itinerary. As long as they make it to the shows on time, I don’t worry and you shouldn’t either.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (offended) I ain’t worried about nothin’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip and Shirley sit in a booth eating lunch. Shirley pick a tuna salad while Lip chows down on a pot roast. Shirley watches Lip, amazed at the ferocity with which he attacks meal.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: How is that? Lip thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Salty. Lip continues to stuff his face. Lip looks Lip feels

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Have you ever thought of being a food critic? up, hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Not really, but...why? Is there money in that?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I’m just saying, you have a marvelous way with words when describing food. Salty. So vivid. One can almost taste it. the jab.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I’m saying it’s salty, and salt’s cheatin’. Any cook can make things salty. But to make it taste good without the salt, with just the other flavors, that’s the trick. See, when you-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: We should be going soon if we expect to get to Pittsburgh by dinner.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: You know, when I was in the army I knew a guy from Pittsburgh, but he called it Titsburgh because he said all the girls there have big tits.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: That's absurd. Why would women in Pittsburgh have larger breasts than, say, women in New York? Lip shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: ‘The hell I know? Guess we'll find out, huh? Lip goes back to his plate.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By the way, when you hired me, my wife went out bought one of your records--‘one about the orphans.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Orphans?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cover had a bunch of kids sitting around a campfire? Shirley has to think a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Orpheus.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Orpheus in the Underworld. It's based on a French Opera. And those kids on the cover? They were demons in hell.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No shit? Must of been naughty kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been driving awhile now. Lip starts to pull the c over to the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I gotta take a leak.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Here? Now?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What, you want me to piss my pants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac stops on the shoulder of the road next to so trees. Lip gets out, takes a few steps... then realizes h forgot something... Lip goes back, opens the driver’s side door and GRABS HIS WALLET OFF THE DASH. Shirley and Lip’s eyes meet for a moment. Then, wallet in hand, Lip heads to the woods to pee.

Lip peers across the courtyard, finds Dr. Shirley sitting the patio outside his room, drink in hand, a half-empty bottle of Cutty beside him. Lip observes a moment, goes back into his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip, wearing a black suit, sits reading a paper. Shirley wearing a tuxedo, enters, crosses to Lip. Shirley pulls a roll of cash out of his pocket, peels off some bills, giv them to Lip.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Take this for any incidentals we may need. If you want something for yourself, you don’t have to ask me, just make sure you keep the receipts. When it runs low, let me know. Lip nods. They walk towards the exit.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One more thing--we will be attending many events before and after the concerts, interacting with some of the wealthiest and most highly-educated people in the country. It is my feeling that your diction, as charming as it may be in the tri-state area, could use a bit of finessing.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Like you mean diction in what way?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: In the only way the word “diction” is ever used.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (unsure) Okay...

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Your intonation, inflection, choice of words--

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Ayyyy, I got my own problems, I gotta worry what other people think about the way I talk?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: There are simple techniques I can teach you that are quite effective. I can help you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lip is frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I don’t need no goddamn help. If people don’t like the way I talk, they can go take a shit.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: The profanity is another issue.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: A fanabla, why you breakin’ my balls?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Because you can do better. And here’s another thing--as guest of honor, I will be announced when I enter these intimate events. You will be announced as well. Vallelonga may be difficult to pronounce. I was thinking “Valle” would be more appropriate. Tony Valle. It’s short and simple.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Nuh-uh. If they got a problem with Vallelonga, they can call me Tony Lip. Shirley winces.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: These are genteel people. That might be a little...worldly for them.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Then it’s Tony Vallelonga. All these high-class people that are so much smarter than me, with all their intelligence and speakin’ abilities, you’re telling me they can’t pronounce my name?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I’m just telling you, Valle will make things easier.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: My last name is Vallelonga and I ain't changing it for nobody. They don't like it, they can shove it up their ass--I'1ll just wait outside. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dr. Shirley considers this.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: A sound compromise.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s your dice, I’m just having a lucky day.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tony! Lip turns to see Shirley at the end of the aisle of parke cars.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: Boss man’s callin’.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: He ain’t my boss. I work for the record company. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lip scoops up his winnings, walks away to the crowd’s dis

dialogues.speaker: BUSBOY
dialogues.text: (calling after him) Come on! Give us a chance to win back our loot!

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Sorry, fellas, duty calls! Lip joins Shirley at the car.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I’ve been looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Sorry. The guys were having a little game.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: If you need extra money, next time, ask me.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: It’s more fun winning it. They reach the Cadillac. Lip opens the back door.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: What if you lost?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (smiles) Craps and cards, I don’t lose, Doc. I don’t lose.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: And stooping down in the gravel throwing dice for pocket change makes you a winner?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What are you giving me shit for? Everybody was doin’ it. Shirley eyeballs Lip.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: They didn’t have a choice whether to be inside or out. You did. This hits a nerve with Lip. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s go. And wipe your knees, you've got dirt on them. Shirley gets in, pulls the car door shut. Lip, embarrasse brushes the dirt off his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Modest, dimly lit. Lip sits at a desk, pen poised. He sta down at a blank piece of paper, takes a breath, starts to write.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: (slow, simple) Dear Dolores... How are you? I am fine... INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - DAY Nick and Frankie are eating lunch as Dolores sits, READS:

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: (reading) “I’m eating real good--hamburgers mostly--so don’t worry about me not eating good. We are doing lots of driving around, and we talk a lot in the car. I saw Dr. Shirley tonight play piano. He doesn’t play like a colored guy. He plays like Liberace but better and I ain’t lying. He’s like a genius I think. When I look at him in the rear-view mirror, I can tell he’s always thinking and working stuff out in his head, I guess that’s what geniuses do. But it don’t look fun to be that smart. I miss you very very much, Baby. Love, Tony. P.S.-- I told you I can’t write letters, ha ha! Regards to your father and brother. I’m going to get a haircut tomorrow. P.S.--Kiss Nickie and Frankie both for me.” As Dolores smiles, we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley's Cadillac drives along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip drives. Next to him, a couple of maps, soda bottles, empty candy wrappers. Shirley sits comfortably in the bac reading glasses on the edge of his nose, reading Allan Drury’s A Shade of Difference. Lip fiddles with the radio, changing stations. Stops on t song Lucille. Lip turns it up. Shirley takes notice.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: On the radio.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Lil’ Richard. Dr. Shirley listens, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: This is Little Richard?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah, he’s good. Think you could play somethin’ like this, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (of course he could) I don’t know. Sounds very complicated. Shirley lowers his book.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So where did this “Tony the Lip” moniker come from?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Not Tony the Lip. Tony Lip--it’s one word. I got it when I was a kid. My friends said I was the best bullshit artist in the Bronx. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lip smiles into the rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Why are you smiling?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You don’t mind that your friends-- the people closest to you--consider you a liar?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (offended) I never said liar, I said bullshit artist.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: What’s the difference?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I don’t lie. I’m just good at, you know, talking people into doin’ things they don’t wanna do. By bullshittin’ ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: And you’re proud of that? Lip shrugs, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Well it got me this job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Caddy whips by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow Twistin’ by Chubby Checker plays on the radio. Lip i looking back at Shirley, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: You’re full of shit! You never hearda Chubby Checker?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Of course I’ve heard of him, I just never heard his music. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I like this. He’s got a silky voice... smooth.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: This is what everyone dances to now --

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Eyes on the road please. Lip flips the station. Aretha Franklin’s Won’t Be Long PL

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: How about this? You know this song.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I don’t think so... Lip looks back at Dr. Shirley in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: How could you not know this music? Chubby Checker, Lil’ Richard, Sam Cooke, Aretha--these are your people! Shirley wears a strained smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip and Shirley's car, followed by Oleg and George’s car, pull into the gas station and parks. Lip gets out, Shirle waits in the car, window open. Oleg and George also get o of their car, stretch, smoke. Lip walks to the novelty shop, which has an outside porch area with multiple displays, knick-knacks, etc. One of th boxes is filled with an assortment of POLISHED STONES of various shapes, sizes, and colors. Lip goes to the box of stones, picks up a few, checks the out, puts them back. Oleg WATCHES AS Lip spot a large JADE-COLORED STONE on th ground. He picks it up, looks it over... Puts it in his pocket... ON DR. SHIRLEY’S CAR - MOMENTS LATER Oleg speaks to Shirley through the back window. Lip exits store, lights a smoke, heads toward Shirley's Cadillac. O goes back to his car. Lip gets in, starts the car. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Before we pull out, Tony, we need to talk. I just heard something that disturbed me a great deal. I gave you petty cash.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah, so?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Oleg told me what you did.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What I do?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You stole a jade stone from the store.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: He watched you do it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I didn’t steal no stone.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You picked it up and you put it in your pocket.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah, I picked a rock up off the ground--I didn’t steal one from the box.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Why would you pick up a rock off the ground?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: ‘Cause that ain’t stealin’. It’s just a regular rock.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (frustrated) But why would you want a regular rock?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (searching) I don’t know, just to have. Like for good luck maybe. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: A lucky rock? Let me see it. Reluctantly, Lip pulls out the JADE STONE.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to go back and pay for it. Lip is embarrassed, angry.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I told you that Kraut was a sneak. Rats me out for something I didn’t even do.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Pay for the stone, Tony, you’ll feel better.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I feel fine, and I’m not paying for no regular rock I found in the dirt. Lip PUTS THE CAR IN DRIVE.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Do not drive, Mr. Vallelonga. Lip stops, puts it in park. They sit in silence. Finally. Lip gets out, SLAMS the door, storms off. Shirley waits. few moments later, Lip gets back in the car, throws it in drive.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Feel better?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Tony, if you’d like, I will happily buy you that stone.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Don’t bother. You took all the fun out of it. As Shirley’s Cadillac pulls back onto the highway, we go.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEGE CAMPUS
dialogues.text: Shirley’s Cadillac pull in front. Lip gets out.  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is empty except for Oleg and George setting up their instruments on stage. As Lip ENTERS, OLEG starts to PLAY A SONG on the Cello. Lip goes to a BROKEN DOWN PIANO on the stage. He looks it over. This can’t be right. He opens the top, inside... GARBAGE... CRUMBLED PAPERS, A COKE BOTTLE, DIRTY NAPKINS. Lip sees the STAGE MANAGER off to the side of the stage.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Excuse me... I’m with the band.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: You’re all set up.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: This ain’t the piano, right? The STAGE MANAGER approaches. This guy’s big, Duke Wayne a hammer holster.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: This isn’t a Steinway...?

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Dr. Shirley only plays on Steinway-brand pianos. It’s in his written contract.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Who's Dr. Shirley?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Dr. Shirley--the Don Shirley Trio?

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Does it really matter?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yes, it does. It’s in his contract. The Stage Manager rolls his eyes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Come on, what’s the difference -- these coons can play on anything. CLOSE ON OLEG AND GEORGE as they stop what they’re doing take notice. BACK ON Lip as he looks closely at the filthy piano.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: But there’s garbage in this thing.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: So, take it out. Lip stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What’d you say?

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: You heard me.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Get a clean Steinway in here.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: There’s no Steinway on campus.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Not my problem.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: I bet there ain’t two Steinways in the whole state of Indiana.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Then you better move your ass and start lookin’. Oleg and George exchange a glance. The Stage Manager puff

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Who you think you’re talking to, greaseball? Without warning, Lip LASHES OUT with a BRUTAL OPEN-HAND S to the Stage Manager’s ear. The Stage Manager STAGGERS BA AND SIDEWAYS. He stares at Lip, dazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Shirley’s fingers tinkle the ivories on a Steinway, performing “HAPPY TALK” to a sold-out house. CLOSE ON THE WING OF THE STAGE where Lip is listening to music, satisfied. The Stage Manager stands a few feet bac from him, looking sheepish and a little scared.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: QUICK MONTAGE AS “HAPPY TALK” CONTINUES...

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “Dear Dolores... This morning I had steak and eggs. For breakfast.” -- DOLORES READING THE LETTER AND SMILING.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “The band has been playing at very ritzy joints. Dr. Shirley and I are getting along pretty good, but sometimes I think he gets depressed and drinks too much." -- CLOSE ON DR. SHIRLEY PLAYING AT A HIGH-SOCIETY PARTY..

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “I never knew how very beautiful this country was. Now that I’m seeing it I know. You wouldn’t believe how beautiful nature is--it is as beautiful as they say. I wish I had a camera and took some pictures, they would be collector’s items, I wish I knew how to describe it to you.” -- DR. SHIRLEY’S CAR DRIVING ON VARIOUS HIGHWAYS, WITH

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “And the traffic out here in the country is nothing, which is fine by me."  49. -- BACK IN THE DINER WHERE LIP IS WRITING THE LETTER.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “Right now I’m eating spaghetti and meatballs in a diner that tastes like ketchup on Chinese noodles. I miss your cooking...” -- SHIRLEY LOWERS HIS NEWSPAPER, GLANCES AT LIP’S CHICKEN SCRATCH PENMANSHIP, SHAKES HIS HEAD. -- SHIRLEY TRIO PERFORMING FOR SEVERAL HUNDRED PEOPLE...

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: “We are heading down south now... I will write you another letter when we get down south. I love you... Your husband Tony... P.S.--Kiss the kids for me...”

dialogues.speaker: -- DOLORES SITS ALONE IN BED, FINISHES READING THE LETTER
dialogues.text: “HAPPY TALK” ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley's car motors past a “WELCOME TO KENTUCKY” sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the radio, “WHOLE LOTTA SHAKIN’ GOING ON,” Jerry Lee L attacking the piano.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Got any family, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Not really? Either you do or you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: It’s a long story, Tony.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What, we’re in a rush now? Shirley takes a BEAT, reluctantly opens up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I have a brother somewhere. We used to get together once ina while...but it got more and more difficult to keep in touch. That’s the curse of being a musician-- you're always on the road, like a carnival worker, or a criminal. (beat) It took a toll on my marriage as well. Lip glances in the rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: You’re married?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Was. They drive for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: June was a good person--terrible grammar, but a kind soul. Unfortunately, I didn’t have the constitution to do a husband act as well as a concert pianist act. I couldn’t balance both worlds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON Kentucky Fried Chicken sign, then we...PAN to th Caddy approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip sits up, excited.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Kentucky Fried Chicken... in Kentucky! When’s that ever gonna happen?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac pulls into the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip looks over the seat-back.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What do you want? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're back on the road, a bucket of Kentucky Fried Chic in the front seat next to Lip. He wolfs down a chicken le he drives.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: This might be the best Kentucky Fried Chicken I ever had. But I guess it’s fresher down here, right? Dr. Shirley shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’ve ever met anyone with your appetite.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No, I bought the bucket so you could have some.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I’ve never had fried chicken in my life.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Who you bullshittin’? You people love the fried chicken, the grits, the colored greens...I love it, too. The negro cooks used to make it when I was in the army.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You have a very narrow assessment of me, Tony.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (pleased) Yeah, I’m good, right?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: What? No. No, you’re not good, you're bad. I’m saying, just because other negro people listen to a certain kind of music doesn’t mean I have to. Nor do we all have to eat the same food. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip looks Lip holds Lip takes Lip takes 52. at Shirley in the mirror. LIP (CONT’D Whoa, wait a minute. If you said all guineas like pizza and spaghetti and meatballs, I’m not gonna get insulted.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You're missing the point. For you to make the assumption that--

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Doc, you want some or not? up the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: No. another big, juicy bite.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Tell me that don’t smell good?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: It smells okay, but I don’t want to get grease on my blanket.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Oooh, I’m gonna get grease on my blankie--have a piece. It ain’t gonna kill ya. a piece of chicken, holds it out to Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just grab it and eat it!

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I’m gonna throw it in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t you dare!

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Then you better take it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: How? Do you even have utensils? Plates?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Bah fongool! Eat it with your hands, that’s how you’re supposed to.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I swear I’m gonna throw it! Shirley reluctantly takes the chicken.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I... I really can’t do this.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Eat_ the goddamn thing. Shirley takes a bite. Lip can see he’s enjoying it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What, no good? Very good.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I just... this seems so... so unsanitary.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: ‘Gives a shit?! Relax and enjoy it. My father always says, whatever you do, do it hundred percent. When you work, work, when you laugh, laugh, when you eat, eat like it’s your last meal. Shirley is clearly enjoying the chicken.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Want another piece? Have a leg! Lip hands Shirley a leg.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: What do we do about the bones?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: We do this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lip throws his bones out the window. After a BEAT, Shirle rolls down his window and does the same. They smile at on another for the first time. Then Lip finishes his Coke an TOSSES THE CUP OUT THE WINDOW. As Shirley loses his smile

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: The Caddy is backing up in the breakdown lane. It stops n to the DISCARDED CUP, Lip’s door opens, he picks it up, a they drive on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Caddy pulls up in front of a RUN-DOWN MOTEL with a “F COLORED ONLY” sign. Low-end, one-level on the edge of downtown. Nothing like the upscale hotels they’ve been staying in. Lip behind the wheel, READING THE GREEN BOOK; Shirley in backseat.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: This can’t be it. Says right here... (points to Green Book) «+.Cozy as your own home... This place looks like my ass.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: This is the place. The guys get out of the car. Lip takes Shirley’s bag out the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: If you need anything, I’1l be up the street at the Easton Inn. So...see you tomorrow. Dr. Shirley takes his bag, walks up the rickety front ste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC from a transistor radio. BLACK FAMILIES sit at tabl outside the motel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shirley, smartly dressed in a DINNER JACKET, sits away fr everyone on the ramshackle porch nursing a glass of CUTTY SARK. SHIRLEY’'S POV - The families are eating, drinking, enjoy the night. CHILDREN run around, playing games, having fun THREE MEN are setting up a game of HORSESHOES in the yard One of the MEN calls to Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hey, fancy-pants, you wanna play?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Um... no, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Come on, we short a man! Shirley shifts in his chair, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I... I'd rather not.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What, you too high and mighty?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: He’s just afraid of getting that butler uniform all dusty! The men LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I’m just... I’m on my way out to meet a friend. Shirley drains his scotch, stands, and WALKS INTO THE NIG INT. LIP’S HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT CLOSE ON BEDSIDE TABLE where we see a wallet, a pack of smokes, and, surprisingly, the JADE ROCK that we thought had returned. PULL BACK to reveal Lip, in boxers, sitting up in bed, flipping through the GREEN BOOK. He puts the book aside a moment, opens a pizza box on the beside him. He takes out the ENTIRE UNCUT PIZZA, FOLDS IT HALF AND TAKES A BITE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He goes back to the book. CLOSE ON the cover - Up top it says Negro Motorist Green Book. Down below reads: “For vacation without aggravation.”

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (reading to himself) Vacation without aggravation... vaffangool. He flips through the book. CLOSE ON A PAGE - It reads: “Assured Protection for the Negro Traveler." Below it the an ad for “Gerald's Restaurant in Buffalo, New York - Delightful Dinners for Particular People -- open 24 hours Lip turns to another page. CLOSE ON PAGE - A photo of Mrs Ressie Harris, the owner of Quinn’s Hotel - “The most fabulous hotel for colored." There’s an URGENT KNOCK ON THE DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tony, it’s George! Wake up! Hurry up! Lip gets up, opens the door. It’s George, sweating and ou breath.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dr. Shirley’s in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Lip hustle down the street.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (panicked) I went out for a drink, I walk into this bar, and there’s Shirley getting bounced around! I didn’t want to leave him, but I didn’t know what to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shit-hole. Drunken REDNECKS surround an EVEN DRUNKER Shirley. LAUGHING as they shove him, smack him around.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Get your hands off him! The Rednecks stop their fun. Bar goes quiet. They turn to Lip and George. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REDNECK
dialogues.text: What the good goddamn we got here, fellas?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Hand him over, we walk out, won’t be a problem.

dialogues.speaker: REDNECK
dialogues.text: Already is a problem, Mister.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (slurring) I just came in for a drink.

dialogues.speaker: REDNECK
dialogues.text: You come in here for a drink? Then you must be tired of livin’, boy.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I told you, hand him over, we’l1l leave. Redneck #2 roughly rubs Dr. Shirly’s head.

dialogues.speaker: REDNECK
dialogues.text: He ain’t going nowhere, we need this brillo pad to wash them dishes with...

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Hey, do yourself a favor and let him go. Now. TENSE BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: REDNECK
dialogues.text: Say it nice.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I just said it nice. The Bumpkins spread out, advance a step. REDNECK #1 pulls a BUCK KNIFE.

dialogues.speaker: REDNECK
dialogues.text: This boy’s gonna get what’s coming to him, and you ain’t got no say! Lip calmly reaches behind his back, under his suit jacket (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Maybe. But, whatever happens, I’m gonna put a bullet right in the middle of that thick skull of yours. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: REDNECK
dialogues.text: He ain’t got no gun, Ray. Let’s get him. He’s fulla shit.

dialogues.speaker: REDNECK
dialogues.text: What if he ain’t? Redneck #1 tries to read Lip’s face... impossible. Lip ca stare down an army.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, I sure ain’t. ANGLE ON - THE BARKEEP, 60s, holding a shotgun, pointing directly at Lip and George.

dialogues.speaker: BARKEEP
dialogues.text: And I won’t be having none of this come to pass in my place. Let the spook go. I want these Yanks off my property. After a BEAT, the Rednecks reluctantly open a path for Sh Shirley staggers toward Lip and collapses against him. Li motions for George to exit, then Lip throws Shirley over shoulder and backs out the door, his eyes peeled for trou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An irate Lip walks an inebriated Shirley throught the par lot of the motel.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What the hell’s wrong with you?! You go in there alone? An unsteady Shirley leans against a car.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (still slurry) I apologize for putting you in that position, Tony. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I don’t understand you, Doc, honest to God. Why couldn’t you just drink here--you got a whole bottle?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I needed some air.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Air?! Don’t you know where you are? Shirley looks at him oddly.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Does the geography really matter?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: If I walked into a bar in your neighborhood, would this conversation be any different? Lip dodges the question.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: From now on you don’t go nowhere without me. Nowhere!

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Tony...Do you really have a gun?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: ‘Course not. Now get some rest. You got a big show tomorrow night. Now where’s your room doc? Shirley points, Lip helps Doc to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip stands off to the side as an ALL-WHITE AUDIENCE watch the Don Shirley Trio give a magnificent performance of th hit, “LULLABY OF BIRDLAND.” When they finish, the crowd ERUPTS in a STANDING OVATION.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Louisville, for your warm hospitality!  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley's Cadillac passes a BILLBOARD that reads: “WELCOM RALEIGH - HOME OF THE N.C. STATE UNIVERSITY WOLFPACK”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip and Shirley drive along looking through bug-smeared windows. Miles and miles of SWEET POTATO fields.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (struggling; slow) “Betty bought... a bit of buttah... but she found the buttah bittah...”

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Not buttah... butter. Say the “er.”

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: “So Betty bought a bit of better butter to make the bitter butter better...”

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: “So Betty bit a buttah...”

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t be lazy--enunciate. “So Betty bought a bit of better butter...”

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: “So, Betty bit a better buttah--” this is bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: No, you need to start somewhere. Athletes stretch to warm up before an event. A singer does vocal exercises. These drills will strengthen your speech muscles. WE HEAR A NASTY “PING” FROM THE ENGINE O.S. STEAM rises f under the hood, splashes against the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Caddy pulls over and Lip steps out into the blazing s Heat waves ripple off the scalding asphalt. Lip removes h jacket, tosses it onto the front seat. He rolls up his sleeves, lifts the heavy Cadillac hood. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shirley rolls down the back window, observes dozens of BL WORKERS laboring in the sun. Men, women, children, bent to the waist, filling woven baskets with sweet potatoes. Shirley steps out of the Cadillac, walks to the front of car where Lip is thigh-deep under the hood. While Shirley leans on the fender, Lip walks to the trunk pulls out a jug of water and a rag. He goes back to the engine, opens the hot radiator cap, pours the water in. Dr. Shirley wipes the sweat beads off his forehead with h suit-pocket handkerchief, looks out onto the fields. One by one the Pickers STAND UP and STARE BACK AT HIM fro BOTH sides of the road. They’ve never seen a black man li him before. Lip crawls out from under the hood, wipes his hands with cloth. He notices the Pickers staring at Shirley. Lip SLAMS the hood, gets in the car. Shirley takes a reflective BEAT... follows.

dialogues.speaker: NORTH CAROLINA PLANTATION
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a stuffed-shirt, MORGAN ANDERSON, 50s, standing the veranda.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, our very special guest from the far north... Don Shirley! APPLAUSE. PULL BACK TO REVEAL an elite Southern crowd surrounding him. CLASSICAL MUSIC drifts from the stereo inside. BLACK WAITERS carry trays filled with champagne a hors d’oeuvres. ANGLE ON a wide-eyed Lip standing with Shirley, Oleg, and George. MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) Accompanying Mr. Shirley, the members of his trio... (reading a small program) Oleg Malakhov, George Dyer, and his associate, Tony Vallla... Valleg...Valle... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shirley, embarrassed, shoots Lip a vague I-told-you-so lo Lip shrugs, he’s not helping. MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) Valley...lohnja. Lip smirks as the PARTYGOERS CLAP. Afterwards, Anderson t back to Oleg and George. MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) Gentlemen, if you don’t mind, I’m going to steal Donnie away for some introductions. As Anderson walks Shirley into the house, Oleg and George grab glasses of sugared bourbon and mingle. Lip looks aro takes it all in. A WAITER approaches with a tray.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Pimiento-cheese sandwich, sir. Lip takes one off the tray, tries it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Oot. Lip SPITS INTO A NAPKIN, plops the BALLED-UP NAPKIN ON TH TRAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guests sit around an immense dining table. Lip sits betwe the Well-Coiffed Woman and an Elderly Woman. Dr. Shirley in the seat of honor to the right of Mr. Anderson, at the head of the table. White-gloved BLACK WAITERS place sterling-silver-covered platters down the length of the table.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Earlier this week, we asked our help what Mr. Shirley might like for supper. So the boys in the kitchen whipped up a special menu in honor of our guest. They lift the platter covers, revealing: Corn on the cob, baked beans, collard greens, grits, and the main course.. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRIED CHICKEN...
dialogues.text: Lip shoots Dr. Shirley a look... See? MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) Don, I do hope you enjoy it! Dig in, everyone! Shirley nods and bites his tongue as a Waiter piles fried chicken onto his plate. WE HEAR THE BEAUTIFUL CHORDS OF “WATER BOY” as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Don Shirley Trio gives a magnificent performance of t biggest hit. As Shirley finishes the song, the room ERUPT APPLAUSE. Dr. Shirley bows.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you...thank you. We will return after a brief intermission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley walks down the hall. He sees a bathroom and start ENTER.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN ANDERSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Don! Shirley turns to see Anderson coming down the hall. MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) Lovely work in there!

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Are you looking for the commode? Here, let me help you. He leads Shirley to a back door, opens it. MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) It’s right out there ‘fore the pines. Shirley looks out, sees an old OUTHOUSE at the edge of th woods.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I’d rather not use that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Don’t be silly, Don. It looks a lot worse from the outside.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I understand. But I’m not going in there. There’s an awkward standoff.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I could go back and use the facilities at my motel, but... that’s going to take at least a half an hour. Anderson considers this for a BEAT, then gives a friendly smile.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN ANDERSON
dialogues.text: We don’t mind waitin’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley stews in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Why don’t I just pull over--you can piss in the woods?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Animals go in the woods.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: But it’s twenty minutes if we go back to your motel.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: So let’s just get there so I can go back and finish the show.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Ayyyy-. See, that’s the difference between you and me. I’d have zero problem goin’ in the woods.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I’m aware. (CONTINUED)
