dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lip glances in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Why you sore at me? I don’t make the rules down here.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: No? Who does? Lip gets the subtext.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Ay are you sayin’ that just ‘cause I’m white and they’re white? That's a very prejudice thing you just said there, a very prejudice thing. I got more in common with the hymies at Second Avenue Deli than I got with these hillbilly pricks down here.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Eyes on the road.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: You know, you always say that when you don’t like what I’m saying.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Eyes on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show's over, GUESTS are departing. As Dr. Shirley accepts congratulations out on the steps, Lip stands by the Cadil smoking with George.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: How does he smile and shake their hands like that? If they tried to pull that outhouse shit with me, I'd piss right on their dining room floor.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don’t do that... Oleg hears this, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: We have many concert dates left. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah...?

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: You realize we are contractually obliged to play them?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Of course I do. If he don’t play ‘em, I don’t get paid. What’s your point? Oleg lights a butt.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: Ugly circumstances are going to happen again... so control yourself. Lip kicks his cigarette out in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Don’t lecture me, you rat.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: Dr. Shirley could've stayed up north getting rear-end kissed at Park Avenue parties for three times money, but he asked for this.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Why? Oleg takes a pull off his cigarette, walks away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. STUCKEY’S RESTAURANT - SOUTH CAROLINA - DAY Lip and Dr. Shirley sit at a table outside. Lip eats pota chips as he WORKS ON A LETTER. Shirley can see that he’s struggling.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: What on God’s green earth are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: A letter.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Looks more like a piecemeal ransom note. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shirley holds his hand out.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I? Lip reluctantly hands him the letter.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reading aloud) “Dear, Dolores--I’m meeting all the highly leading citizens of the town, people who use big words, all of them, but you know me, I get by, I’m a good bullshitter.” (to Lip) Two “t"s in “bullshitter.” (continues reading) “As I’m writing this letter, I’m eating potato chips and I’m starting to get thirsty. I washed my socks last night and dried them on the TV. I should have brung the iron." (to Lip) You know this is pathetic, right? Lip shrugs, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me what you’re trying to say. Lip looks up.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) I don’t know. Just... you know, how I miss her and shit.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Then tell her that. But try to say it in a manner that no one has ever said it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Shit...

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: And without profanity. Shirley gives the letter back to Lip, then starts to pace (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put this down. “Dolores, when I think of you, I’m reminded of the beautiful plains of Iowa.” Lip stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put it down. Lip starts to write.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (repeating) “When-I-think-of-you-I ’m-reminded- of-the-beautiful..." Lip looks up.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Plains of Iowa.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What planes?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: The plains. P-L-A-I-N-S. Those big fields we saw.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Oh, those were nice. (writing) “,..plains of Iowa--which is what they call big fields around here.”

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Tony, no expounding. Lip looks up, confused.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No what?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Just write what I say. Shirley keeps pacing as he thinks.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “The distance between us is breaking my spirit... My time and experiences without you are meaningless to me.” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lip writes feverishly to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (repeating) “,..Are meaningless to me.” Lip starts to write again.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Now this... “Falling in love with you was the easiest thing I have ever done.” Eyes glued to the page, Lip SCRIBBLES AWAY FURIOUSLY.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: “Falling in love with you was the easiest thing...” (looks up, smiling) This is very fucking romantic. As Lip continues writing, we go... INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Dolores sits on the couch reading the letter, the kids as next to her... In her head, she HEARS LIP’S VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Nothing matters but you. I am the luckiest man alive, and every moment I am without you, I realize this. Dolores can barely believe the poetry pouring out of her husband.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I loved you the day I met you, I love you today... Dolores is PRACTICALLY IN TEARS and we go... BACK ON SHIRLEY AS HE FINISHES DICTATING THE WORDS.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Is it okay if I say, “P.S., kiss the kids”? Shirley breaks from his trance.

dialogues.speaker: A P.S.
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah, at the end.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: That's like clanging a cowbell at the end of Shostakovich’s 7th. Lip nods as if he knows what Shirley’s talking about.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (hopeful) So it’s okay? Dr. Shirley can’t say no to the child in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: It’s perfect, Tony. Lip smiles and writes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip and Shirley walk down the street. They pass by a MEN’ CLOTHING STORE and Shirley stops to look in the window. ANGLE ON STORE WINDOW -- a WHITE MANNEQUIN dons a high-en British-style suit and vest.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: That guy looks just like you, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: He does?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (realizing) Size-wise. Shirley studies the suit, considering it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go in and try it on. What, you always gotta wear a tux on stage? Mix it up a little. INT. MEN’S CLOTHING STORE - DAY - MOMENTS LATER As Lip and Shirley ENTER, a couple BUSINESSMEN are trying suits. A TAILOR approaches Lip.

dialogues.speaker: TAILOR
dialogues.text: May I help you, sir? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: We want to try on that suit in the window.

dialogues.speaker: TAILOR
dialogues.text: Of course. The Tailor pulls a suit off the rack, hands it to Lip.

dialogues.speaker: TAILOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dressing room’s in the back, sir. Lip hands Shirley the suit.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Thanks. I’1l just be a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Take your time. I’1l check out some ties for ya. The Tailor REACTS, follows Shirley toward the dressing ro

dialogues.speaker: TAILOR
dialogues.text: Uh, excuse me, you’re not allowed to try that on.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon? The Tailor takes the suit from him.

dialogues.speaker: TAILOR
dialogues.text: If you would like to purchase it first, we'll be happy to tailor it to your needs. Shirley stares at him a moment, gets it, and heads for th ANGLE ON Lip at the tie rack, watching all this. Frustrat he glares at the Tailor and follows Shirley out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Don Shirley Trio is in top form as they finish playin spirited rendition of BLUE SKIES. The song reaches a crescendo, the crowd BURST INTO APPLAUSE, and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. LIP’S HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT Lip’s in the BATHROOM washing his socks in the sink. WE H ALFRED HITCHCOCK PRESENTS coming from the 0.S. TELEVISION THE PHONE RINGS O.S. Lip goes to the bed, passing the television. WE SEE black socks hanging on the rabbit ears antenna and some underwe drying on the vents of the TV. Lip answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip enters the YMCA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip approaches POLICEMAN #1 standing beside a swimming po

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I got a call about Dr. Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Come on... Lip follows the Policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Policeman #1 enters the locker room followed by Lip. Dr. Shirley, BRUISED, is handcuffed, sitting on the floor naked (also seen from the side). His skin still wet from steam room and sweat. Next to him also naked and cuffed t the radiator, is a WHITE MAN. Policeman #1 walks Lip over to POLICEMAN #2, African American.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: This is him.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Can you give the guy a towel, for Chrissakes? No one moves. Lip grabs a towel off a rack and throws it Shirley, who covers himself as best he can.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: You a lawyer? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Well you should call one. We’re taking your Auntie in.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Manager caught him and the other guy... The Cop motions to the Caucasian Man in cuffs. Lip glances over at the dazed and humiliated Shirley. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Can’t we get the cuffs off him, let him put his pants on?

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Sure we can. But we ain’t.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Look, we’re out of here in the morning, you'll never see us again. There’s gotta be a way to work this out. (scrambling) What if, uh, you let him go, and I give you something to thank you?

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: You bribing us?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No, no... a thank you.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: What kind of thank you?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Like... a donation to the police force. To you guys. Whatever you want. (thinks ) You like suits? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was walking through your nice town today, I saw a store that was selling suits. Nice suits. The cops glance at one another.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about, as a thank you--a donation--I buy you guys each a suit? You get dressed up nice, take your wives out to dinner. Guys like you, you deserve it. The two Policemen glance at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley trails Lip as they EXIT the YMCA and walk toward parking lot. No one speaks. Then...

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (subdued) They were wrong for the way they treated me, and you rewarded them. We see that Shirley’s eye is bruised, his lip slightly swollen.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I was hired to make sure you get from one show to the next. How I do it shouldn’t matter to you.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I just wish you hadn’t paid them off.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I did what I had to do. You know, if this got out it would kill your career.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Okay, Tony, quit your phony altruism and concern for my career.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What the hell does that mean? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You were only thinking about yourself back there, because you know if I miss a show, it comes out of your pocket.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Of course I don’t want you to miss a show, you ungrateful bastard! You think I’m doing this for my health?! Tonight I saved your ass, so show a little appreciation. Besides, I told you never to go nowhere without me!

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (calmly) I assumed you would want this to be the exception. Lip gets in the car without opening Shirley’s door. Shirl stands alone a moment, then opens his own door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac drives past a WELCOME TO TENNESSEE sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley’s Cadillac pulls up. The windows are closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip and Shirley sit for a moment. It’s clear they haven’t spoken for a while.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (re: bruises) Should I try to find you some make- up or somethin’ before the show?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I said I’m fine.  76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip gets out of the car, opens Shirley’s door.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tony Lip! Lip turns to see TWO NEW YORK WISEGUYS standing out front waiting for their car. The mouth of the group is pug-nose DOMINIC.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Dominic. The hell you doin’ here?

dialogues.speaker: WISEGUY
dialogues.text: Brooklyn sent us down to take care of a few things. He glances at Shirley, who’s waiting by the hotel entranc

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: (in Italian) Who’s the eggplant? CLOSE ON - Shirley, waiting for Lip by the hotel entrance

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (in Italian) I’m working for him. BACK TO LIP AND DOMINIC.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: (in Italian) What’d you lose a bet? One of the wiseguys LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in Italian) What’s wrong with you? You need work, you come to me! I’ll always find work for you. Matter of fact, I can use you this week. Gotta hit a few joints, straighten some people out--you’ll make some real money.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (in Italian) I’m making money. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: (in Italian) Whatever he’s paying you, I’1l double it. Lip glances at Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (in Italian) This isn’t the place to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: (in Italian) Meet me in the bar at eight o’clock sharp. Forget this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A concerned-looking Don Shirley sits in front of the mirr in his room. He takes make-up from a SMALL KIT and dabs a his lip and bruised cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dominic sits at the bar, having a drink. Wiseguy #1 enter walks over to Dominic.

dialogues.speaker: WISEGUY
dialogues.text: I just called his room. He’1l be down in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip comes out of his room, locks his door.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Lip turns to see Shirley behind him in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Oh. Hey. Just... downstairs. For a drink.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (in Italian) To meet your friend, Dominic? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lip is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in Italian) Before you decide whether or not to take him up on the job offer, I think we should have a word. Lip realizes that Shirley understood the earlier conversa

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in English) Tony, I think you’re doing a wonderful job. Lip shrugs, not used to Shirley being so solicitous.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I would like to formally offer you the position of my road manager. With the title comes more responsibility and, of course, there will be a raise in pay. Lip thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No, thanks. Shirley nods, disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You and me, we agreed on a hundred and twenty-five a week, plus expenses. That’s our deal. I ain’t goin’ nowhere, Doc. I’m just goin’ down to tell ‘em. A surprised Shirley watches Lip walk to the stairway.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Tony... Lip stops, looks to Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry about last night. Lip nods. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Don’t sweat it. I been workin’ nightclubs in the city my whole life...I know it’s a complicated world. As Lip heads downstairs, WE PUSH IN on Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Shirley and Lip sit at a table in the lobby. Shirley pours them both a drink from a bottle of Cutty Sark.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: So, how'd you learn how to play so good, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: My mother. She taught me how to play on an old spinet. Soon as I could walk, we’d travel around the Florida panhandle and I'd put on little shows in parishes and halls. A man who had seen me play arranged for me to study at the Leningrad Conservatory of Music.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: So that’s where they taught you all them songs you play?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Actually, I was trained to play classical music. Brahms, Franz Liszt, Chopin--it’s all I ever wanted to play. (smile fades) But I was persuaded by my record company to pursue a career in popular music instead. They told me audiences would never accept a black pianist on the classical stage. Wanted to turn me into just another “colored entertainer.” You know, the guy who smokes while he’s playing, who puts a glass of whisky on the piano and then gets mad when he’s not respected like Arthur Rubinstein. Well, you don’t see Arthur Rubenstein smoking and putting a drink on his piano. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Personally, if you stuck to that classic stuff I think it would’ve been a big mistake.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: A mistake? Performing the music I trained my entire life to play?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Trained? What are you, a seal? Anyone can sound like Beethoven or Joe Pan or them other guys you said. But your music, what you do, only you can do, and nobody can train for that. Shirley thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Tony. (beat) But...not everyone can play Chopin...not the way I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weather has cooled. Lip sits on a bench SCRIBBLING wh a bundled-up Shirley paces and WAXES POETIC.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (dictating) “,..The trees have shed their leafy clothing and the colors have faded to grays and browns, but my heart bursts with reds and blues and greens from the love I hold inside for you...” INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Dolores reads the letter ALOUD to Louie’s wife, Lynn, and Johnny's wife, Fran. In the b.g., we see the guys--Grandp Nicola and Anthony, Louie, Rudy, Johnny--at the kitchen t PLAYING CARDS.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: (reading aloud) “It's getting colder as we travel, but the country is still beautiful. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I saw millions of trees, all dusted with snow, just like out of a fairy- tale...” Lynn and Fran are enthralled.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: He’s so expressive. Dolores smiles proudly.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: “We've only a few more shows before our Christmas concert in Birmingham, Alabama on the 23rd. I will count the hours, minutes, and seconds until you are in my arms. I love and miss you more than I can explain. Tony. P.S.--Kiss the kids.” CLOSE ON THE GUYS playing cards in the kitchen. They coul help overhearing Dolores.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Gotta admit, Lip’s letters--they’re not bad.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Well, it’s in the family. They say we had a great, great, great grandfather helped Da Vinci with the Sixteen Chapel.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You mean Michelangelo.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Right. And that’s a true story, right, Pop?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: What the hell’s that got to do with writin’ letters?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I’m just sayin’, we’re an arty family. Frances yells to John.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: John, I want a letter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, soon as you make a meal... As the guys CHUCKLE, Shirley’s song “THE LONESOME ROAD” begins PLAYING, and we go to... A MONTAGE OF THE NEXT COUPLE WEEKS... --Shirley’s Cadillac barrels down a southern highway. The bare trees along the road show SIGNS OF THE COMING WINTER

dialogues.speaker: HALL.
dialogues.text: --LIP AND SHIRLEY’S CAR STOPPED AT A LIGHT. A car pulls up next to them. The COUPLE inside, 30s, star stir, as they notice that Lip, a white man, is chauffeuri black man. The couple gawks rudely at them. Lip looks ove smiles, and FLIPS THEM THE BIRD.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (admonishing) Tony... As they drive off, we ANGLE ON Shirley, who cracks a tiny --SHIRLEY’S CADILLAC DRIVES THROUGH A RURAL LANDSCAPE DUS WITH SNOW.

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO MAN
dialogues.text: Let’s give a fine Louisiana welcome to Don Shirley and the Don Shirley Trio! The GROUP gives him rousing APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain pounds the pavement, THUNDER. The Cadillac’s HEADLIG fight to cut through the darkness.  83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TORRENTIAL RAIN HAMMERS THE ROOF OF THE CAR. Visibili is zero, the wipers aren’t helping. Frustrated, Lip wipes windshield with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Your mother’s ass... Through the rear window, A PAIR OF HEADLIGHTS. Shirley lo back. THE CAR FOLLOWS THEM.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Hell’s this guy doin’? SUDDENLY RED LIGHTS FLASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEADY RAIN... Shirley's Cadillac pulls over, stops. The Highway Patrol Car tucks in close behind them. TWO HIGHWAY PATROLMEN IN RAIN GEAR exit their cruiser, approach Shirley’s Cadillac, shine FLASHLIGHTS into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PATROLMAN #1'‘s flashlight beams through the driver’s win almost blinding Lip. A tap on the window. Lip opens it.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: License and papers?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Glad to see you guys. I’m a little lost. Lip hands Patrolman #1 his papers. ANGLE ON Shirley sitting quietly in the back as PATROLMAN 20s, fresh-faced, shines his flashlight through the windo

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: (to Lip) Step out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: In the rain? What I do? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Out of the car. Patrolman #1 opens the door, Lip gets out. Lip stands in the dark, muddy road, the red police lights flickering off his drenched face. PATROLMAN #1 (CONT’D) Why you on this road?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I told you, I had to detour and I’m lost. We’re not from around here.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: No, you ain’t. So I’m gonna ask you again... what the hell you doin’ out here? (glances at Shirley) And why you driving him? Patrolman #2 keeps the light shined on Dr. Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: He’s my boss. The Patrolmen look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: He can’t be out here at night. This is a sundown town.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: (to Patrolman #2) Get him out of the car. Check his I.D.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Come on, it’s pouring. The young Patrolman looks to his senior partner.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: I can just get it through the window.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Get him out the goddamn car! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Patrolman #2 opens Shirley’s door.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Out. Shirley gets out in the rain. Patrolman #1 studies Lip’s license.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: What’s this last name say?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Vallelonga.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: ‘Hell kind of name is that?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Italian.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, now I get it. That’s why you driving this boy around... you half a nigger yourself.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: (shaking) Hands in the air, now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip sits on a concrete slab in a small cell. Shirley peer through the bars out at Patrolmen #1, #2, and the grizzle POLICE CHIEF, 50s.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Excuse me! (no response) Excuse me, sirs. I quite understand why my associate is being held, but what exactly am I being charged with? Not a glance in his direction. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You seem like reasonable men--can you let me out so we might discuss the situation please?

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Put the apple butter away, boy--you ain’t goin’ nowhere no time soon. Dr. Shirley’s demeanor hardens.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You cannot hold me without cause!

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: I got cause. ‘Cause you let the sun set on your black ass! The Chief LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I want to speak to a lawyer, I want my phone call! This is a flagrant violation of my rights! I demand my phone call immediately! The younger officer looks to the Chief, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: He does have...rights. The Chief glares at him. Finally, the Chief looks at Patrolman #1.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHIEF
dialogues.text: Give the negra his goddamn call. Reluctantly, Patrolman #1 goes to the cell, unlocks it, w Shirley to a side office. The cop picks up the phone, holds it out to Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: You know a lawyer? Call him. As the cop steps away, Shirley pulls a SMALL BLACK BOOK o of his jacket pocket, flips to a page, DIALS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip sits on the floor, stone-faced. Shirley paces the roo increasingly annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: As my mother always said, “What kind of brand new fool are you?!” Lip doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look out there, Tony. Take a good look at the officer you hit. Lip doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at him. Lip raises his eyes. HIS POV - Patrolman #1 is sitting in the bullpen, drinkin coffee, horsing around with the other cops.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s having a grand old time, chatting up his pals, having a nice cup of coffee. And where are you? In here. With me. Who did nothing. Yet I’m the one who’s paying the price. I’m the one who’s going to miss the Birmingham show.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m losin’ a lot of money, too, if you don’t play Birmingham. Shirley steps in front of Lip.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: So your little temper tantrum...was it worth it? (beat) You don’t win with violence, Tony, you win when you maintain your dignity. Dignity always prevails. And tonight, because of you, we did not. The station PHONE RINGS and Patrolman #2 answers.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Mayersville Po-lice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The young cop STRAIGHTENS UP, color draining from his fac PATROLMAN #2 (CONT’D) (into phone) No, sir. Not me, sir. Yes, sir, he’s right here, sir. He holds the phone out to the Chief.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHIEF
dialogues.text: What? The rookie is too stunned to speak. Finally, the Chief gr the phone.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHIEF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chief Pratt--who’s this? (beat) Bull-oney. Patrolman #2 waves frantically and the Chief starts to sw He stands, starts to pace.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHIEF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, yes, now I hear it, Governor. I’m sorry. Yes, of course I recognize your voice. (shrinking) I-I’'m sorry, you sayin’ the boy we got locked up called who, sir? (beat) And he called you? The rattled Chief glances at Shirley and Lip--who the hel are these guys? We HEAR the 0.S. Governor SCREAMING AT HI over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHIEF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But an officer was assaulted in the line of... (backing down) No, no, I don’t want no National Guard down here, neither, sir. (wilting) Yes, Governor, immediately. And good night to you and the missus. The Chief hangs up, turns to Patrolman #1.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHIEF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let ‘em go.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: What?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHIEF
dialogues.text: Cut ‘em loose, goddamnit! ANGLE ON SHIRLEY and a STUNNED LIP watching all this.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: But that dago-wop hit me!

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHIEF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now! BACK ON COPS - Defeated, Patrolman #1 hurries over to the cell, opens it up. Lip turns to Shirley, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Who the hell’d you call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac FLIES PAST a sign reading: “WHITES ONLY WITH CITY LIMITS AFTER DARK.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip wears a mad, shit-eating grin as he drives through th SLASHING RAIN on the way out of town.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Bobby Kennedy just saved our asses! Maddon...How great is that?!

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: It’s not great--it’s not great at all--it’s humiliating. Lip glances in the rear-view.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: ‘The hell you talking about? We were screwed and now we ain't.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: And I just put the Attorney General of the United States in an incredibly awkward position.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: So what? That’s what the guy gets paid for. What else he got to do? Shirley glares at Lip. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: That man and his brother are trying to change this country--that’s what else he’s got to do! Now he thinks I’m garbage. Calling from some backwoods swamp jail, asking if he can help attenuate assault charges... who does that? Garbage, that’s who. This stings Lip.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You_shouldn’t have hit him!

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I didn’t like the way he was treating you, making you stand out in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Please. You hit him because of what he called you. I’ve had to listen to that kind of talk my entire life, you should be able to take it for one night.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What, I can’t get mad when he says that stuff ‘cause I’m not black? Christ, I’m blacker than you. Shirley REACTS to this.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You're blacker than me?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: You don’t know shit about your own people! What they eat, how they talk, how they live--you don’t even know who Lil’ Richard is!

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: So knowing who Little Richard is makes you blacker than me? I wish you could hear yourself sometimes, Tony--you wouldn’t talk as much. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Bullshit! I know exactly who I am. I’m the guy who’s lived on the same block in the same Bronx my entire life, with my mother and father and my brother, and now my wife and kids. That’s it--that’s who I am. I’m the asshole who’s gotta hustle every goddamn day to put food on my table. You? Mr. Big Shot? You travel around the world and live on top of a castle and do concerts for rich people! I live on the streets, you sit on a throne--so yeah, my world is way more blacker than yours!

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Pull! Over!

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I ain’t pullin’ over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip steers the car to the side of the road. Shirley opens door, gets out in the rain. Lip looks out the window as Dr. Shirley walks down the drenched, muddy road.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What are you doin’?! When Shirley doesn’t stop, Lip gets out, hustles after hi

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get back in the car! Shirley keeps walking. Lip catches up, grabs his arm. Shi turns, his face drenched... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, I live in a castle! Alone. And rich white folks let me play piano for them, because it makes them feel cultured. But when I walk off that stage I go right back to being another nigger to them--because that is their true culture. And I suffer that slight alone, because I’m not accepted by my own people, because I’m not like them either! So if I’m not black enough, and I’m not white enough, and I’m not man enough, what _am I?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony doesn’t know what to say. They stand in the rain whi Shirley tries to compose himself. Lip awkwardly touches Shirley's shoulder. Shirley turns and walks back to the c leaving Tony standing alone in the downpour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on the road, both of them disheveled and wiped out f the evening. Nobody speaks for a while.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I need sleep.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Okay, I’11 pull over at the next place we see and I’1l sneak you into my room.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: No. No. I refuse to stay at an establishment that doesn’t want me.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Okay. Lip picks up the Negro Moterist Green book from the seat to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A COLOREDS ONLY sign out front of a ramshackle b building. PAN TO the Caddy pulling into the DIRT PARKING LOT full o puddles and BEAT-UP CARS.  93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip lays in a sunken twin bed in his t-shirt and underwea WRITING A LETTER. Shirley, in silk pajamas, folds his clo and places them into his suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You realize you're going to be home before that letter gets there?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was gonna just bring it with me. Save on stamps. Shirley rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Give it here, I'll fix it. Shirley reaches for the letter, but Lip pulls it away.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No offense, Doc, but I think I got the hang of it. For a moment, Shirley's offended. Then he SNATCHES THE LE out of Lip’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: (reading) “Dear Dolores, sometimes you remind me of a house.” Shirley glances at Lip... what the hell?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reading) "RK house with beautiful lights on it where everyone inside is happy.” Shirley hands the letter back to Lip.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, you got it. Shirley gets in bed, tries to sleep. We hear O.S. cars; occasionally a dog barks in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Doc...

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Yes? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Thanks for helping me with the letters--you’re really good at writin’ ‘em. (beat) Maybe when you get home you should write one to your brother?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: He knows where I am if he wants to reconnect. Lip nods. He puts his letter down, turns out the light.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Don't wait for him, Doc. This I know...the world’s full of lonely people afraid to make the first move. Shirley thinks about this, then rolls over.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, something’s been eating at me the whole trip.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: That Tittsburgh was a real disappointment. I didn’t notice any difference at all.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Good night, Tony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Caddy motors by on its way to Birmingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley's Cadillac drives through the city.  95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BANNER across this large wooden hotel reads: “CHRISTMAS CONCERT TONIGHT -- DON SHIRLEY TRIO”. THE CADDY PULLS UP FRONT AND PARKS. Lip and Shirley get out. Waiting for them is GRAHAM KINDE 40s, blue blazer, pressed slacks, friendly as hell.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: (deep southern accent) Welcome, Mr. Shirley! Graham Kindell, I’m the general manager. So nice to meet y'all!

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Kindell. This is Tony Vallelonga.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: Pleasure, Tony. Right this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip and Shirley (carrying his tux) follow the affable Kin through the large working kitchen. COOKS, BUSBOYS, DISHWASHERS, ALL BLACK. They continue down several busy hallways to a backstage dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: If you need anything--anything t’all--you let me know.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kindell leads Shirley and Lip into the modest room. A sma table, one chair, a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: Here you are. We have about an hour before show time. Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Where’s the restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: Continue down the hall, Tony, to the right, across the lobby. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kindell EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: We’ve got an hour. I’m starving.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Go ahead. I’1l meet you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cavernous DINING ROOM/HALL. Ornately decorated in red a green ribbons and wreaths. A twenty-foot Christmas Tree towers behind the Trio’s instruments onstage. Filling in with well-dressed WHITE CUSTOMERS. Lip ENTERS, sits at a table. HIS POV - Across the room, Oleg and George eat dinner, dr wine. George CALLS OUT:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Tony! George waves him over. Lip joins them.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Shirley’1l be here in a minute. A WAITER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BIRMINGHAM WAITER
dialogues.text: Cocktails, gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: Three shots vodka. Tony looks at Oleg.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Last show. Cold war over. Time for truce. Lip nods, smiles. The Waiter leaves to get the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is Shirley in his dressing room?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: More like a broom closet. I don’t understand why he puts up with this shit. Oleg takes a sip of wine, glances at George. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: Six years ago, 1956, Nat King Cole was invited to perform at Municipal Auditorium right here in Birmingham. Mr. Cole was very first negro asked to play at a white establishment in this city. Lip butters a roll, takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Soon as Mr. Cole started playing, a group of men attacked him for playing white people’s music. Pulled him off stage and beat him badly. Lip stops chewing.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You asked once why Dr. Shirley does this? I tell you. Because there is no genius without courage. 97. The Waiter returns with the drinks. They CLINK glasses, d the shots. Lip NOTICES Shirley (now in his tux) and the MAITRE D’ ha a conversation at the entrance. Lip walks over.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What’s the problem?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: This gentleman’s saying I can’t dine here.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: (to Maitre D’) No, you don’t understand, this guy's playing here tonight--he’s the main event. MAITRE D’ I’m sorry. It’s the policy of the restaurant. Graham Kindell, the congenial GM, joins them.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: Everything all right? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No, it’s not all right. Dr. Shirley's being told he can’t eat here.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: (to Shirley) I apologize, but these are... long- standing traditions. I’m sure you understand.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: No. I don’t. In 45 minutes I’1l be entertaining your guests up on that stage, but I can’t eat here? Graham Kindell shifts uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You’re tellin’ me the bozos in his band, and the shlubs that came to see him play can eat here, but the star can’t? Customers take notice. It’s getting embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: I’m afraid not. Lip looks to the stoic Shirley, then back to Kindell, searching for a compromise.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Well he’s gotta eat. Can you at least bring him food from the restaurant to his dressing room?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: Of course. We’ll be happy to send him anything he would like. (to Maitre D’) John, show him a menu.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: No. I’m not eating in a dressing room. There's a brief standoff. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: Okay... if you’d prefer, there’s a very popular establishment right down the road--the Orange Bird-- they'll be happy to feed you. Lip turns to Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Food’s probably better there anyway --the dinner rolls here are like rocks. Come on, we can be back in 45 minutes. When Shirley doesn’t respond, Lip pulls him aside.

dialogues.speaker: LIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Doc, it’s the last show. Let’s just get through this and we can go home and get away from all these assholes. Dr. Shirley thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: No. Not this time. I’m eating in this room or I’m not playing. Kindell’s frustration grows.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: (to Lip) May I have a word with you? Lip follows Kindell through a door, into a side parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kindell tries to pour on the Southern charm.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: Mr. Villanueva, you have to talk sense to Mr. Shirley. Please explain that we’re not insulting him personally, this is just the way things are done down here.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah, well he ain’t from down here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: Just ask him to be reasonable. I have 400 guests out there who expect to be entertained tonight.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: And Dr. Shirley expects to eat tonight. Why can’t you just make an exception this one time? Kindell SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: Lemme tell you a story. You ever hear of the Boston Celtics basketball club? Those boys came through here a couple years ago on a barnstorming tour. Now, seeing as they were World Champions of the league and all, we was tickled to have ‘em eat here and we rolled out the welcome wagon. So you know what table their big coon ate at that night?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: I don’t either. But it wasn’t one of ours. Kindell drops the genteel demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now let’s cut the bullshit. Tell me what it’s gonn’ take. Kindell takes out his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Say one hundred dollars and you get your boy to play? The veins on Lip’s neck rise.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: You think you can buy me?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: All do respect, sir, but you wouldn't be doing a job like this if you couldn’t be bought. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lip GRABS Kindell by the collar, raises a fist.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Stop! They turn to see Shirley in the doorway. Graham Kindell p away from Lip, fixes his collar.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s all right, Tony. I’1l play... if you want me to. Graham Kindell SIGHS, clearly relieved. Lip is relieved, But only for a moment. Something comes over him. He glanc at Kindell, then back at Shirley. Lip finally sees the bi picture, and realizes that, for him and Shirley, this is moment of truth. Then...

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Nah, let’s get the fuck outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip escorts Shirley through the crowded ballroom toward t exit with Graham Kindell on their heels in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL
dialogues.text: Don, don’t do this! Shirley and Lip keep moving at a brisk pace through the surprised and bewildered crowd.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have a contract, and I know you're the kind of man that honors a contract! ANGLE ON the BLACK SERVERS watching their boss grovel. Th maintain deadpan expressions, but we can see the APPROVAL THEIR EYES.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM KINDELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got a show to do, mister! Scattered BOOS and CATCALLS from the diners as the FURIOU Graham Kindell follows them out the front door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull onto the street and drive in silence, both in s about what just happened. Shirley looks at Lip in the rea

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a Blues Bar/Restaurant. Lip and Shirley ENTER. A small BAND in the corner--piano, drums and guitar--plays BLUES. Lip’s the only white guy in here and he doesn’t go unnoticed, especially standing next to Shirley in a tuxed They make their way to the bar, sit. A female BARTENDER g Lip the once-over.

dialogues.speaker: ORANGE BIRD BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You a cop?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I look Irish? She smirks.

dialogues.speaker: ORANGE BIRD BARTENDER
dialogues.text: What you want, baby?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Two Cutty’s, neat. Shirley takes out a BIG WAD OF CASH. A couple DRUNKS at t bar take notice.

dialogues.speaker: ORANGE BIRD BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Comin’ up. She grabs a bottle of Cutty, pours the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Whatever your specialty is, we’ll take it. She CALLS back toward the kitchen:

dialogues.speaker: ORANGE BIRD BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Two orange birds!

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Lip and Shirley are devouring two barbecue chickens, thei hands and faces covered in orange sauce.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I like what you did back there, Doc. You stood up for yourself. It’s like your friend the President says -- “Don’t ask what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for yourself.” Shirley smiles. The Bartender approaches.

dialogues.speaker: ORANGE BIRD BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (to Shirley) So, darlin’, what you do, all dressed up like that? He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Nothing important.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: He’s only the greatest piano player in the world. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ORANGE BIRD BARTENDER
dialogues.text: That right? You good?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Don’t be shy, Doc. Tell her who you are.

dialogues.speaker: ORANGE BIRD BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me nothin’--show me. Shirley thinks a moment, glances at the BEAT-UP PIANO. He gets up, walks to the stage, sits at the piano. He notice drink on the top of the piano. Shirley takes the drink, p it on the floor. SHIRLEY PLACES HIS HANDS ON THE KEYS, TAKES A MOMENT... And then... Shirley starts to play. This isn’t a catchy j solo or a Christmas ditty. It is, instead, an explosion o sound, the eye-popping machinations of Chopin’s Etude Op. No. 11, one of the most difficult piano solos ever writte The crowd lower their forks and gaze up in disbelief. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON Lip watching this in awe. Black kitchen workers stop what they’re doing to watch. A COOK steps out of the kitchen, wiping his hands on his ap BACK ON SHIRLEY as he negotiates the eight-finger chord combinations with the mastery of the maestro that he is. He builds and builds and builds until his fingers become A BLUR ON THE KEYS. Shirley FINISHES, the room is quiet. Then the place ERUPTS IN APPLAUSE! CLOSE ON Lip. He’s as blown away as the audience. Shirley looks toward a stunned Lip and winks. The GUITAR PLAYER, DRUMMER, and SAX join Shirley on the stage. They start a cool up tempo rockin’ blues number. Shirley effortlessly joins in, taking the music to anothe level. The entire room begins to PULSATE. The crowd eats up. Shirley plays as if Little Richard had taken over his bod Obviously this man can play anything. A true musical geni ANGLE ON Lip as he looks on, really getting into it. BACK ON SHIRLEY, the happiest we’ve seen him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exhausted Shirley and Lip are dragging themselves acro the parking lot toward the Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: If we leave right now, I think you can make it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Make what?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Christmas Eve. Lip stops walking, holds his hand in front of Shirley. Li reaches behind his back, PULLS OUT A GUN, SHOOTS INTO THE AIR. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON CUE, one of the runks from the bar, knife in hand, jum out from BEHIND THE CADDY and SPRINTS OFF, followed by th other drunk. THEY HIGH-TAIL IT OUT OF THERE. Shirley look Lip, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Don’t ever flash a wad of cash ina bar. As Lip walks to the car...

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I knew you had a gun!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac breezes down the highway in a light rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LIGHT SNOW flicks against the windshield. Lip checks ou the ominous sky.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: This could get bad.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s a shame we don’t have something to protect us on our journey. Dr. Shirley thinks, then SNAPS his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don’t you put your lucky rock up on the dash, Tony? Lip stares at him in the mirror for a LONG BEAT. Finally, reaches in his pocket, pulls out the JADE STONE THAT WE THOUGHT HE HAD RETURNED, places it on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. I feel safer already. Lip wears a tiny smile.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: You're a real prick, you know that?  106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s SNOWING HEAVILY now and conditions have worsened. Th Caddy is one of the only cars on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Caddy passes by, BLOWING UP A SHEET OF SNOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip squints, trying to focus, WIPERS FLAPPING VIOLENTLY, visibility awful.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Doc, my eyes are stingin’, I might need to pull over.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Keep going as long as you can, Tony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lonely Cadillac fights through the NORTHEASTER as conditions get more and more treacherous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tense-looking Lip struggles to keep the car on the road SUDDENLY A BLUR OF RED LIGHTS FILLS THE CAR FROM BEHIND. glances in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac pulls over in the slush, a MARYLAND STATE PO CAR right behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An annoyed Lip sits waiting for the Cop. A LIGHT beams through the window. Lip rolls it down, revealing a MARYLAND STATE TROOPER.

dialogues.speaker: STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: We're trying to get to New York. The Trooper flashes his light on Shirley in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Is there a problem, Officer? TENSE BEAT, THEN...

dialogues.speaker: STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: Yeah. I noticed your car was tilting to the left. Looks like your back tire’s flat. Lip opens the door, glances back at the snowy flat tire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The State Trooper DIRECTS TRAFFIC SAFELY AROUND THEM as L jacks up the car in the storm.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Lip SHUTS THE TRUNK and gets back in the car. The Trooper approaches his window.

dialogues.speaker: STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: Okay... be careful, gentlemen. Merry Christmas. This is the first flicker of humanity they’ve experienced a while. As the Trooper walks away, Lip and Shirley glanc each other, smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Caddy drives through a blizzard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip blinks repeatedly as he tries to concentrate on the r From the 0.S. RADIO, we HEAR: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Weather advisory warning this Christmas Eve, aS a major snowstorm is hitting the eastern seaboard with the severest weather in eastern Pennsylvania, northern New Jersey and the five boroughs. Travelers are advised to stay off the Jersey Turnpike, as well as the bridges and tunnels leading into New York City, due to possible road closures...”

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: That’s it. I’m pulling us into the next motel.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Keep going, Tony, you can make it.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: I can’t keep my eyes open, Doc--I’m gettin’ hytnotized by the snow. I think my brain’s gonna explode. As we PUSH IN on a disappointed Shirley, we...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: SPINNING ALBUM...
dialogues.text: “HAVE YOURSELF A MERRY LITTLE CHRISTMAS” FROM THE FRANK SINATRA CHRISTMAS ALBUM plays on a record player.

dialogues.speaker: SINATRA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Have yourself a merry little Christmas...” The tiny apartment is filled with CHRISTMAS DECORATIONS,

dialogues.speaker: WITH TWINKLING LIGHTS IN THE CORNER.
dialogues.text: The dining room table has been moved into the living room accommodate all the guests. Grandpa Anthony, Grandpa Nicola, Rudy, Louie with his wif Lynn and their baby, Johnny with his wife Fran, their two little DAUGHTERS, and Nick and Frankie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everyone’s in good cheer, talking, drinking wine, eating appetizers. Dolores is busy putting platters of THE FEAST THE SEVEN FISHES, all fish dishes cooked Italian style, o table. Stuffed Calamari, Baked Clams Oreganata, Fried Fil Sole, Fried Calamari & Shrimp, Linguini with Clams, etc. KITCHEN - Dolores moves into the kitchen, now alone. She braces herself on the counter, tries not to cry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SNOW AND SLEET POUND THE EMPTY STREETS. The snowflakes reflect red, white, and green from the lights that adorn buildings. There’s not a moving vehicle in sight. Then... IN THE DISTANCE, one lonely set of CAR LIGHTS appears. PU IN SLOWLY, SLOWLY until the lights get closer and we can OUT that it’s THE CADDY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip’s STRETCHED OUT in the back seat, SLEEPING. PULL BACK reveal DR. SHIRLEY AT THE WHEEL, FOCUSING INTENTLY. We can HEAR the 0.S. SOUND of the CADILLAC’S WHEELS SPINN as Shirley negotiates the slippery streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip still sleeping in the back seat. He’s jolted awake by someone BANGING on the window.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tony, wake up! THE SNOW CONTINUES TO FALL... The Caddy is parked in fron Lip’s apartment building. Shirley stands on the sidewalk, Lip’s bag on the ground beside him. Shirley opens the bac door. Lip looks up, groggy. He realizes he’s home.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: What... Doc, whadja’ do? Shirley helps Lip climb out of the car. He hands Tony his suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You’re home. Go inside.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Doc, why don’t you come up, meet my family...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, Tony. Shirley gets in the car. Lip’s stunned, this can’t be how ends.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Doc, wait up! Hey... Lip watches as the car drives off, the tail-lights of the Caddy disappearing into the snowy night. INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Jimmy Roselli’s “BUON NATALE (MEANS MERRY CHRISTMAS TO YO PLAYS on the stereo. Dinner is winding down. Everyone at table is stuffed and having a festive time, except...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores, who fights the good fight for her guests. THE KITCHEN - Dolores comes in, starts putting dirty plat in the sink... She HEARS A COMMOTION coming from the livi room... THE LIVING ROOM - Everyone jumps up from their seats as L ENTERS, brushing snow off his coat, singing an Italian so

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Hey, look who it is--Shakespeare’s home! The kids run into their father’s arms. Everyone crowds ar Lip, hugging, kissing... Dolores enters from the kitchen, stands watching... Dolores and Lip gaze at each other... She moves to him, w her arms around his neck, they kiss. The family breaks in applause.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: You kiddin’? I’m starving. They all laugh, sit at the table.

dialogues.speaker: CARNEGIE HALL
dialogues.text: We can barely see the building through the snowfall.  111. INT. SHIRLEY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT - MOMENTS LATER Shirley ENTERS his apartment, followed by his valet, Amit who carries Shirley’s luggage.

dialogues.speaker: AMIT
dialogues.text: Welcome home, Dr. Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Amit.

dialogues.speaker: AMIT
dialogues.text: I turned down your bed, sir. Will you be needing anything else?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: No, thank you. Go home to your family.

dialogues.speaker: AMIT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Doctor. Merry Christmas. Amit EXITS. Suddenly SHIRLEY IS ALL ALONE. He glances aro his apartment at the throne, the elephant tusks, all his possessions. The room is quiet. Dr. Shirley reaches in his pocket, takes out the JADE STO He PLACES IT ON HIS MANTEL, next to some other artifacts.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Lip and stuffed picking talking the entire family are at the table. Lip has an over- cannoli in front of him while everyone else is away at a large assortment of desserts. Everyone’s except for Lip, who seems happy but distant.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Tony, s’matter with you? You haven't said a word.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Yeah, sorry, just tired. Long trip. (under breath, to Johnny) You take care of that thing?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. He pulls something out of his pocket and hands it to Lip UNDER THE TABLE. (CONTINUED)
ANGLE UNDER THE TABLE - we see that it’s Tony’s WRISTWATC Lip puts the watch on.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You owe me seventy-five bucks. Lip REACTS.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Charlie said sixty.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: What, I’m doing this for nothin’? Lip shoots Johnny a look.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Lip, tell us about the trip.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. So how was he, the tootsune? He get on your nerves? Lip shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Don’t call him that. Rudy’s taken aback. Embarassed.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Okay... ANGLE ON DOLORES watching this. She looks surprised by Li reaction to the slur. A pleasant surprise. The family’s surprised too. Everyone’s quiet. Dolores changes the subj

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: Tony, you should’ve seen the day last week when Frankie grabbed onto the TV and climbed up on it! I took a picture...

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: Are you nuts, Dee? With all those tubes back there, and the cord--he could've got electrocuted! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You’re thinkin’ of toasters. No one’s gettin’ electrocuted from a TV. As everyone starts to ARGUE about toasters and TVs, there KNOCK ON THE DOOR. Lip gets up, goes to the door. He open it, REACTS. Charlie from the pawn shop stands in the doorway with his wife, Marie.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: PAWN GUY
dialogues.text: Hey, Lip. Johnny invited me.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: PAWN GUY
dialogues.text: You remember Marie.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Hi, Marie, Merry Christmas. Johnny gets up from the table, greets Charlie and Marie.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Charlie, you came? I was kidding? And you brought the wife, too? He takes them to the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, everybody, Charlie from the pawn shop. Can you believe it? Christmas, he didn’t bring nothing! Charlie, I’m kidding, sit down... Lip turns to shut the door and sees - Dr. Shirley, standi in the doorway, holding A BOTTLE OF CHAMPAGNE, looking unsure. Tony Lip smiles and hugs him, walks him in. Lip turns to family, excited.

dialogues.speaker: LIP
dialogues.text: Everyone, this is Dr. Donald Shirley! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas. REVERSE ANGLE reveals Johnny, Nicola, Rudy, Louie, Anthon everyone... watching them, STUNNED AND SPEECHLESS. No one budges. Shirley smiles nervously. LONG BEAT. Then finally Johnny stands.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Well, come on, make some room! Get the man a plate! Dolores approaches Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: You must be Dolores. She smiles and he hands her the champagne.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHIRLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Buon Natale. Thank you for sharing your husband with me. Lip smiles. Dolores hugs Shirley and WHISPERS in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: DOLORES
dialogues.text: And thank you for helping with the letters. Shirley, surprised, laughs. CLOSE ON DOLORES - She smiles, and we -- CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: EPILOGUE
dialogues.text: Dr. Donald Shirley continued to tour, compose, and record was awarded the Isaac Stern Medallion, and was the only o Carnegie studio resident, besides Leonard Bernstein, who performed annually at Carnegie Hall. During his prolific career, he composed three symphonies, piano concerti, a cello concerto, three string quartets, one-act opera, a symphonic tone poem based on Finnegan's Wake, and a set of "Variations" on the legend of Orpheus the Underworld. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frank “Tony Lip” Vallelonga went back to his job at the Copacabana, eventually becoming Maitre’ D, until its clos in 1973. It was at the Copa where he met Francis Ford Coppola, who cast him in a small role in The Godfather. This led to an impressive acting career, including roles in Raging Bull, Pope Of Greenwich Village, Donnie Brasco, and Goodfellas. Lip is best known for his portrayal of New York crime bos Carmine Lupertazzi in the HBO series The Sopranos. Tony Lip and Dr. Shirley would remain lifelong friends un their deaths within months of each other in 2013.
